newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT--Mark crosses to punish dollar/mark.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT--Mark crosses to punish dollar/mark.

text.p: After getting a boost versus the yen from a weak Japanese economic report, the dollar may be, this time, at the mercy of the mark's fortune.
Dollar/yen climbed on Wednesday as Japan's Tankan or Beige Book depicted an unexpectedly bearish mood among businesses.
Dollar/yen ended the American session at 108.42/47 after testing 108.50 resistance. Clearing that level, analysts say, would leave the field open for a run at 108.70, then 109.15.
But it was the mark that benefitted the most from the yen's demise, garnering additional momentum from the Tankan's effect on the European crosses.

"What seems to have had an effect on dollar/mark is that mark/yen broke a two-month trendline at around 73 the figure," said analyst Ben Morden at I.D.E.A. "Mark/yen could be an important cross rate tomorrow as it seems to still have the momentum to reach the cycle high at 73.78."
Dollar/mark closed virtually unchanged on Wednesday in New York at 1.4765/70.

Borden predicted dollar/mark would suffer from fresh mark/yen gains. The mark could also climb versus other Europeans, mainly the French franc or the Italian lira -- both vulnerable to budget deficit worries.
Analysts said the loss of 1.4740/1.4715-mark area would pave the way for a slide to 1.4650 and 1.46. They also noted mark/Swiss is near 0.8080, a key level for future mark gains.
Borden said Swiss/yen is signaling a new mark/yen advance and thus more pressure on dollar/mark.

"Swiss/yen is pushing above 91.40 which is, in itself, a confirmation of the mark/yen rally and a buy signal for mark/yen," Morden noted. "We're seeing a lot of knock-on effects that began with the Tankan release."
Mark/Paris is also nearing the top of its old band in the European Rate Mechanism at 3.4305.
The 3.4305 level is psychologically important due to market sentiment France wants to be in the European Monetary Union with mark/franc at a parity that would meet the old ERM standards.

"It's important psychologically but also in terms of technical levels because that is close to 3.4285, a 10-month, 50-percent retracement level," Borden said of mark/Paris while noting "this is precisely to the tick where we topped out today."
